The Federal Food and Drug Administration approved Enovid, a birth control medication, in 1960.
Enovid and similar birth-control medications were largely responsible for the increase in numbers of teenagers having premarital sex during the “sexual revolution” of the 1960s.

In this example, the opinion links the availability of birth control medications to an increase in premarital sexual activity and claims the medications are “largely responsible,” a claim that, though possible, cannot be definitively proved.
Abstinence is the only method of birth control that is 100 percent effective against pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections.
Teenagers would be more willing to recognize the benefits of abstinence if the media didn’t constantly glamorize sex.
In this example, the opinion blames the media for teenagers’ unwillingness to refrain from premarital sex, although the extent to which the media may or may not influence behavior cannot be proved.
STIs such as chlamydia, gonorrhea, and genital herpes are transmitted during sexual relations.

Advocating abstinence for teenagers is a battle that cannot be won. Teachers and parents would better serve teenagers by educating them about the dangers of STIs and stressing the necessity of practicing safe sex.

In this example, the statement makes the unprovable claim that teenagers will not embrace abstinence and attempts to convince readers that sex education offers a better approach to the issue of premarital sex.

The Guttmacher Institute reported in 2021 that more than 90 percent of American parents support sex education in high school that covers topics including STIs, healthy relationships, and birth control.
Comprehensive sex education is the best form of sex education
In this example of an opinion, "best" is a value judgement that cannot be proven.
